lessons.title: What is a Computer Keyboard?
lessons.content:
A computer keyboard is an input device used to type letters, numbers, and symbols into a computer. It works like the keyboard on your phone or typewriter, but it has many more keys and functions.

1. What It Does:
The keyboard helps you tell the computer what to do — by typing commands, words, or numbers. For example, when you type a message or your name, you use the keyboard.

2. How It Looks:
A keyboard has many buttons called keys, arranged in rows. Most keyboards have between 80 and 110 keys.

3. Fun Fact:
The word ‘keyboard’ means a board with keys! Without it, it would be very hard to use a computer.

lessons.title: Layout of the Keyboard
lessons.content:
The keyboard layout shows how all the keys are arranged on the keyboard. The most common layout is called the QWERTY layout because the first six letters on the top letter row are Q, W, E, R, T, and Y.

Parts of the Keyboard Layout:
👉 Typing area – where you find letter, number, and punctuation keys.
👉 Function keys – the row at the top (F1 to F12) used for special actions.
👉 Navigation keys – used for moving the cursor (arrows, Home, End).
👉 Numeric keypad – found on the right side for typing numbers quickly.
👉 Control keys – like Ctrl, Alt, and Shift for shortcuts.

lessons.title: Categories of Keys
lessons.content:
The keys on a keyboard are grouped by what they do. Here are the main categories of keys:

1️⃣ Alphabet keys – A to Z letters used for typing words.
2️⃣ Number keys – 0 to 9, used for typing numbers.
3️⃣ Function keys – F1 to F12, used for special tasks like opening help or refreshing pages.
4️⃣ Arrow keys – move the cursor up, down, left, or right.
5️⃣ Control keys – like Ctrl, Alt, Shift, and Esc, used with other keys for commands.
6️⃣ Punctuation keys – for symbols like ! , ? . ; and : .
7️⃣ Numeric keypad – a group of number keys on the right side for quick calculations.

lessons.title: How to Use the Keyboard for Typing
lessons.content:
Typing is the skill of pressing the right keys quickly and correctly. Good typing skills make computer work faster and easier.

1. Posture for Typing:
✅ Sit straight on a chair.
✅ Keep both feet flat on the floor.
✅ Keep your fingers curved over the keys.
✅ Don’t bend your wrists too much.

2. Home Row Rule:
Start typing with your fingers on the Home Row Keys — A, S, D, F, J, K, L, ;
The left hand controls A, S, D, F and the right hand controls J, K, L, ;

3. Practice:
Use online typing tutors or games to improve your speed and accuracy.

lessons.title: Function Keys (F1–F12)
lessons.content:
The Function Keys are the special keys at the top of the keyboard, labeled from F1 to F12. Each key has its own job or command that helps you work faster on the computer. Their functions can change depending on the program you are using.


🖱️ Here’s What Each Function Key Does:

  • F1 – Opens the Help window in most programs. (Example: If you are stuck, press F1 for help!)
  • F2 – Used to rename a selected file or folder quickly. Just click on a file and press F2 to change its name.
  • F3 – Opens the search feature in many programs or browsers so you can find things faster.
  • F4 – In Windows, pressing Alt + F4 closes the active window or program. (Use it to quickly close a page!)
  • F5 – Used to refresh or reload a webpage or document. Try it when a page isn’t showing updates.
  • F6 – Moves the cursor to the address bar in most web browsers. Helpful for typing website links quickly.
  • F7 – Opens the spelling and grammar check tool in Microsoft Word and some other writing programs.
  • F8 – Commonly used to access Safe Mode when starting a computer (for troubleshooting).
  • F9 – Refreshes or sends/receives emails in Microsoft Outlook. Also updates formulas in Excel.
  • F10 – Activates the menu bar in many programs. With Shift + F10, it acts like a right-click on a selected item.
  • F11 – Turns the browser into full-screen mode. Press again to return to normal view.
  • F12 – Opens the Save As window in Microsoft Word. You can use it to save a copy of your work quickly.

💡 Extra Tips:

  • You can hold Fn (Function key) with F1–F12 on laptops to activate special actions like volume, brightness, or Wi-Fi.
  • Each function key can do different things depending on the software you are using.

In short: Function keys help you work faster and smarter. Try using them to explore shortcuts and make computing fun!

lessons.title: Home Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Home Row Keys are the central row of the keyboard where your fingers rest while typing.

👉 Left hand: A, S, D, F
👉 Right hand: J, K, L, ;

These are called the home row because your fingers always return here after pressing any key. It helps you type faster and reduces mistakes.

Tip: There are small bumps on F and J keys to help you find them without looking.

lessons.title: Top Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Top Row Keys are located just above the home row and include letters like Q, W, E, R, T, Y, U, I, O, P.

When typing, you move your fingers slightly upward to reach these keys. They are often used in many English words — for example, ‘type’, ‘word’, and ‘you’.

Fun Fact: The QWERTY layout got its name from the first six letters of this row!

lessons.title: Bottom Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Bottom Row is found below the home row and contains keys such as Z, X, C, V, B, N, M, comma, and period.

This row also includes important keys like Spacebar, Ctrl, Alt, and Windows key.

Tip: The Spacebar key is the longest key and it adds space between words when typing.

lessons.title: Punctuation Keys
lessons.content:
Punctuation keys help you make your sentences clear and correct. They include:
👉 Full stop (.)
👉 Comma (,)
👉 Question mark (?)
👉 Exclamation mark (!)
👉 Colon (:) and semicolon (;)
👉 Quotation marks (‘ ’ and “ ”)

Tip: Use punctuation to show pauses, questions, or excitement in your writing.

lessons.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
lessons.content:
Keyboard shortcuts are special key combinations that help you perform tasks quickly without using the mouse. They save time and make your work faster and easier.

What Are Keyboard Shortcuts?
Keyboard shortcuts use one or more keys pressed together to tell the computer to do something. For example, instead of moving your mouse to click 'Copy', you can press Ctrl + C.

Common Keyboard Shortcuts:
✅ Ctrl + C – Copy selected text or files
✅ Ctrl + V – Paste what you copied
✅ Ctrl + X – Cut (remove and copy) selected text
✅ Ctrl + S – Save your document
✅ Ctrl + Z – Undo your last action
✅ Ctrl + A – Select all
✅ Ctrl + P – Print
✅ Alt + Tab – Switch between open windows
✅ Ctrl + Alt + Delete – Open Task Manager (to close or restart apps)

Windows Shortcuts:
🪟 Windows + E – Open File Explorer
🪟 Windows + D – Show or hide the desktop
🪟 Windows + L – Lock your computer
🪟 Windows + R – Open the Run box
🪟 Windows + I – Open Settings
🪟 Windows + Shift + S – Take a screenshot

Typing Special Characters:
✨ Use the Alt key with numbers to type symbols (on the numeric keypad):
➡ Alt + 0169 → © (Copyright)
➡ Alt + 0174 → ® (Registered mark)
➡ Alt + 0153 → ™ (Trademark)
➡ Alt + 0216 → Ø (Empty set symbol)
➡ Alt + 3 → ♥ (Heart)

Function Keys (F1 – F12):
🔹 F1 – Help
🔹 F2 – Rename a file or folder
🔹 F5 – Refresh a page
🔹 F11 – Full screen mode

Benefits of Using Shortcuts:
👉 Work faster and smarter
👉 Reduce mouse use
👉 Avoid strain from too much clicking
👉 Look like a computer pro!

Fun Practice Tip:
Try learning one new shortcut each day. Write them on sticky notes and keep beside your keyboard until you remember them!

lessons.title: Home and End Keys
lessons.content:
The Home and End keys help you move quickly when typing or reading on your computer. They are usually found near the arrow keys on your keyboard.


💻 What They Do:

  • Home Key – When typing in a line of text, pressing Home takes your cursor to the beginning of that line.
  • End Key – Moves your cursor to the end of the line you are typing.

📘 Examples:

  • If you are writing: “I love computers.” and your cursor is at the end, press Home to jump back to the ‘I’ quickly.
  • Press End to jump from the beginning of a sentence to the last word instantly.

🔀 When Used with Other Keys:

  • Ctrl + Home – Moves to the very beginning of a document or webpage.
  • Ctrl + End – Moves to the very end of a document or webpage.

In short: The Home and End keys help you move around your text or page faster, saving time and effort while typing!

lessons.title: Arrow Keys
lessons.content:
The Arrow Keys are the four keys that point Up, Down, Left, and Right. They help you move around on your computer without using the mouse.


🎮 What They Do:

  • Up Arrow (↑) – Moves the cursor or object upward.
  • Down Arrow (↓) – Moves the cursor or object downward.
  • Left Arrow (←) – Moves the cursor or object to the left.
  • Right Arrow (→) – Moves the cursor or object to the right.

🧠 Common Uses:

  • Scroll up or down in a document or webpage.
  • Move a character in computer games.
  • Navigate cells in a table or spreadsheet.

Tip: Combine arrow keys with Shift to select text or items in a list.

lessons.title: Control Keys (Ctrl)
lessons.content:
The Control key (Ctrl) is used together with other keys to perform quick commands called keyboard shortcuts. There are usually two Ctrl keys on a keyboard – one on the left and one on the right.


✨ Common Ctrl Shortcuts:

  • Ctrl + A – Selects all text or items.
  • Ctrl + B – Makes selected text bold.
  • Ctrl + C – Copies the selected item.
  • Ctrl + V – Pastes what you copied.
  • Ctrl + X – Cuts the selected text or file.
  • Ctrl + Z – Undo the last action (go back one step).
  • Ctrl + S – Save your work.
  • Ctrl + P – Print the document.
  • Ctrl + F – Find a word in a document or webpage.

In short: The Ctrl key helps you work faster by combining it with letters for powerful shortcuts.

lessons.title: Shift Key
lessons.content:
The Shift key is used to type capital letters and special symbols. You can find two Shift keys on your keyboard, one on each side.


📝 Uses of the Shift Key:

  • Capital Letters: Hold Shift and press a letter key to type a capital letter (Example: Shift + a = A).
  • Symbols: Hold Shift to type the upper symbols on number keys. (Example: Shift + 2 = @).
  • Highlight Text: Use Shift + Arrow Keys to select text without using a mouse.

In short: The Shift key changes what other keys do, helping you type neatly and accurately!

lessons.title: Number Keys
lessons.content:
The Number Keys are the keys with numbers 0–9. You can find them above the letter keys and also on the numeric keypad (on some keyboards).


🔎 Uses of Number Keys:

  • Type numbers in your documents, forms, and games.
  • When used with Shift, they type special symbols. Example: Shift + 1 = !, Shift + 2 = @, Shift + 3 = #, and so on.

Fun fact: The numeric keypad on the right side helps you type numbers faster — just like a calculator!

lessons.title: Numeric and Symbol Keys
lessons.content:
Numeric and symbol keys help you enter numbers and special characters.

1. Numeric Keys:
These are the number keys 0–9 located above the alphabet keys and also on the numeric keypad.
Example: You use them when typing your age (10) or doing sums (2 + 3).

2. Symbol Keys:
These include signs like ! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + etc. They are typed by holding the Shift key and pressing another key.

3. Uses:
Symbols are used in email addresses, passwords, and mathematics.

lessons.title: What is a Computer Mouse?
lessons.content:
A computer mouse is a small device used to move the pointer on the computer screen. It helps you click, select, drag, and open items. The mouse sends signals to the computer as you move it.

Examples:
🖱️ Moving the mouse moves the pointer on the screen.
🖱️ Clicking opens files or programs.

Fun Fact: The mouse got its name because its wire looked like a tail!

lessons.title: Types of Computer Mouse
lessons.content:
There are different types of computer mice depending on how they work and connect to the computer.

1. Mechanical Mouse: Uses a rubber ball to detect movement.
2. Optical Mouse: Uses a light sensor to detect movement (most common today).
3. Wireless Mouse: Connects to the computer using Bluetooth or a USB receiver — no wire needed!
4. Touchpad: Found on laptops; you move your finger to control the pointer.

Example: A laptop uses a touchpad instead of a physical mouse.

lessons.title: Mouse Buttons and Their Uses
lessons.content:
A standard mouse has two or three buttons:

🟦 Left Button: Used to select, open, or click items.
🟩 Right Button: Opens a short menu called a context menu with options.
🟨 Scroll Wheel: Used to move up and down a page easily.

Tip: Most mice also allow you to press the scroll wheel as a button to open links in a new tab.

lessons.title: Mouse Actions
lessons.content:
Mouse actions are movements or clicks you perform to control the computer.

Common Mouse Actions:
🖱️ Point: Move the pointer over an item.
🖱️ Click: Press and release the left mouse button once.
🖱️ Double-click: Quickly press the left button twice to open items.
🖱️ Right-click: Press the right button to open a menu.
🖱️ Drag: Hold down the button and move the mouse to move an item.

lessons.title: Drag and Drop
lessons.content:
Drag and drop means moving an object from one place to another on the screen using the mouse.

Steps:
1️⃣ Point to the item you want to move.
2️⃣ Hold down the left mouse button.
3️⃣ Move (drag) the mouse to the new location.
4️⃣ Release the button to drop it.

Example: You can drag an icon from the desktop into a folder.

lessons.title: Scrolling with the Mouse
lessons.content:
Scrolling means moving up and down on a page or document using the scroll wheel.

How to scroll:
🔹 Roll the wheel forward to move up.
🔹 Roll the wheel backward to move down.

Tip: You can also hold the scroll bar at the side of the screen and drag it to move through long pages.

lessons.title: Clicking Basics
lessons.content:
Clicking is one of the most important mouse skills!

Types of Clicking:
🖱️ Single Click: Selects an item.
🖱️ Double Click: Opens an item or program.
🖱️ Right Click: Shows options for the selected item.

Practice: Try single-clicking and double-clicking icons on your desktop!

lessons.title: Clicking and Dragging
lessons.content:
Clicking and dragging is a way to select or move items.

Example 1: Click and drag the mouse to highlight words in a document.
Example 2: Click and drag a picture to move it to another folder.

Tip: Release the mouse button when you want to drop the selected item.

lessons.title: High-Speed Precision Tasks
lessons.content:
Some computer tasks require careful and accurate mouse movement.

Examples:
🎨 Drawing in Paint programs.
🕹️ Playing games that need fast reaction.
📂 Dragging files into small folders.

Tip: Move the mouse slowly for better control when selecting small items.

lessons.title: Mouse Practice Activities
lessons.content:
Practice makes you better with the mouse! Here are some fun exercises:

✅ Open Paint and try drawing simple shapes.
✅ Practice drag and drop icons on your desktop.
✅ Use scrolling to read a long webpage.
✅ Try double-clicking to open programs.

Goal: Become fast and accurate when using the mouse!

lessons.title: What is a Computer?
lessons.content:
A computer is an electronic machine that receives data (input), processes it, and gives results (output). It can perform tasks very fast and accurately when given correct instructions. Computers help us type letters, draw pictures, play games, and learn new things.

Examples of computers include desktop computers, laptops, tablets, and smartphones.

Main functions of a computer:
1. Input – Receiving information (like typing or clicking).
2. Processing – Working on the data.
3. Output – Showing the result (like display or print).
4. Storage – Saving information for later use.

In summary, a computer is a smart helper that makes work easier, faster, and more accurate.

lessons.title: Parts of a Computer
lessons.content:
A computer is made up of hardware and software.

1. Hardware – These are the physical parts you can touch and see.
Examples:
• Monitor – Displays text and pictures.
• Keyboard – Used to type letters and numbers.
• Mouse – Helps move and click on items.
• System Unit (CPU) – The brain of the computer that processes information.
• Printer – Prints out documents or pictures.
• Speakers – Produce sound.

2. Software – These are the programs or instructions that tell the computer what to do.
Examples:
• Microsoft Word
• Paint
• Scratch
• Web browsers (like Chrome)

Without hardware, you cannot touch the computer, and without software, the computer cannot work.

lessons.title: Uses of a Computer
lessons.content:
Computers help us in many areas of life. Here are important uses of computers:

• Education – Learning new topics, typing, and watching lessons.
• Home – Listening to music, playing games, and watching cartoons.
• Office – Writing letters, keeping records, and preparing reports.
• Banks – Keeping customer records and printing receipts.
• Hospitals – Storing patient information and checking results.
• Transportation – Booking tickets and controlling traffic.

Activity for pupils: Name three ways computers help people in your community.

lessons.title: Safe Use of Computers
lessons.content:
Computers are fun to use, but we must use them safely and responsibly.

1. Health and Safety:
• Sit properly when using the computer.
• Keep your eyes a little away from the screen.
• Avoid using the computer for too long.
• Wash your hands before and after use.

2. Device Care:
• Do not eat or drink near the computer.
• Always shut down properly after use.
• Keep computer cables safe.

3. Online Safety:
• Do not share personal information with strangers.
• Tell a teacher or parent if something online looks bad.
• Never click on unknown links or adverts.

Remember: Being safe keeps you healthy and protects your computer.

lessons.title: Introduction to Coding
lessons.content:
Coding means writing instructions that tell a computer what to do. Just like we use English to talk to people, we use programming languages to talk to computers.

Examples of coding activities:
• Making a game or animation in Scratch.
• Writing instructions to make a robot move.

Why learn coding?
• It helps you think logically.
• It improves creativity.
• It teaches problem-solving.

Example: In Scratch, you can code a cat to move when you press the space key.

lessons.title: Scratch and Block Coding
lessons.content:
Scratch is a colorful coding tool for kids. It uses blocks that you can drag and drop to make programs — no typing needed!

Features of Scratch:
• Fun characters called sprites.
• A stage where your story or game appears.
• Blocks for movement, sound, and looks.

Examples of block coding:
• Move 10 steps.
• Turn right 15 degrees.
• Say 'Hello!' for 2 seconds.

Why kids love Scratch:
It is easy to use, fun, and helps children learn how to make games, animations, and stories.

lessons.title: Algorithms for Kids
lessons.content:
An algorithm is a step-by-step way to solve a problem. Computers follow algorithms to complete tasks.

Example: To make tea, your algorithm might be:
1. Boil water.
2. Put tea bag in cup.
3. Pour hot water.
4. Add milk and sugar.
5. Stir and drink.

In coding, algorithms tell the computer what to do in steps.

Simple Example in Scratch:
When green flag clicked → Move 10 steps → Turn 15 degrees → Say 'Hi!'

Activity: Write an algorithm to brush your teeth!

lessons.title: Introduction to the Internet
lessons.content:
The Internet is a global network that connects computers all over the world. It allows people to share information, send messages, and learn new things.

Uses of the Internet:
• Sending and receiving emails.
• Watching videos and listening to music.
• Searching for information on Google.
• Chatting with friends and family.

Requirements to use the Internet:
• A device (computer, tablet, or phone).
• A modem or data connection.
• A browser (like Chrome or Edge).

Remember: Always use the Internet responsibly and safely.

lessons.title: Working with Files
lessons.content:
A file is a collection of data or information stored on a computer. Files can contain text, pictures, music, or videos.

Types of files:
• Text files – Documents and notes.
• Image files – Pictures and drawings.
• Audio files – Music or recordings.
• Video files – Movies and clips.

What you can do with files:
• Create – Make a new file.
• Save – Keep your work for later use.
• Open – View a saved file.
• Rename – Change the name of a file.
• Delete – Remove a file you don’t need.

A folder helps to keep your files organized, just like your school bag keeps your books.

lessons.title: Using the Internet
lessons.content:
When using the Internet, you must know how to browse safely and wisely.

Steps to browse:
1. Open your browser (like Chrome or Firefox).
2. Type a web address (like www.google.com).
3. Press Enter to visit the page.
4. Click on links to open other pages.

Common Internet activities:
• Search for information.
• Send and receive emails.
• Watch educational videos.
• Play safe online games.

Internet Safety Tips:
• Never share your password.
• Avoid downloading unknown files.
• Get permission before visiting websites.

The Internet is a world of knowledge — use it wisely!
